references.title: Inhibition of Manganese Dissolution in Mn2O3 Cathode with Controllable Ni2+ Incorporation for High-Performance Zinc Ion Battery
High-Performance Reversible Aqueous Zn-Ion Battery Based on Porous MnOx Nanorods Coated by MOF-Derived N-Doped Carbon
Non-Metal Ion Co-Insertion Chemistry in Aqueous Zn/MnO2 Batteries

sections.text:
S-1
Supporting Information to
Boosting the Cycling Stability of Aqueous Zinc-Ion Batteries through
Nanofibrous Coating of Bead-like MnOx Cathode
Liyan Ding1, Jiechang Gao1, Tianran Yan1, Chen Cheng1, Lo-Yueh Chang2, Nian Zhang3, Xuefei Feng4, and Liang Zhang1*
1. Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials (FUNSOM), Jiangsu Key Laboratory
for Carbon-Based Functional Materials & Devices, Soochow University, 199 Ren'ai Road, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China
2. National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu 30076, Taiwan 3. State Key Laboratory of Functional Materials for Informatics, Shanghai Institute of
Microsystem and Information Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200050, China 4. National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, University of Science and Technology
of China, Hefei 230026, China
*Corresponding author. Email: liangzhang2019@suda.edu.cn
S-2

sections.heading: Experimental section
sections.text: Mn(NO3)24H2O, 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), ZnSO47H2O and MnSO4H2O were purchased from Aladdin Co. Ltd. Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, Mw = 130000) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Acetylene black and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) were obtained from Taiyuan Lizhiyuan Technology Co., Ltd. Stainless steel foil and zinc foil were purchased from SCI Materials Hub. Nonwoven filter paper was purchased from Sontara MicroPure AP.

sections.heading: 1. Preparation of Mn-MOF spheres
sections.text:
In a typical process, 0.75 mmol Mn(NO3)24H2O was dissolved in 50 mL ethanol to form the solution A and 0.4 mmol BTC was dissolved in 30 mL ethanol to form the solution B. Then, the mixture of solution A and B was stirred for 30 min to form a homogeneous transparent solution. The Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) was used to load the above solution and then placed in an oven at 160 ℃ for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was washed by ethanol for several times and vacuum dried at 60 ℃ overnight.
S-3

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of MnOx-CNFs
sections.text:
1 g PAN and 1.3 g Mn-MOF were dissolved in 10 mL DMF via vigorously stirring for 6 h to get a brown homogeneous mixture. Then the above mixture was transferred into a plastic syringe with a stainless needle connected to the channel of the electrospinning. The flow rate is 0.8 mL h-1, and the distance between the collector and the needle was ~15 cm by using 15 kV in the needle. After electrospinning procedure, the as-spun nanofibers were peroxided in air at 280 ℃ for 2 h and carbonized under N2 at 800 ℃ for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 ℃ min-1. Subsequently, the carbonized fibers were oxidated in air at 350 ℃ for 1.5 h. MnOx-CNFs was thus obtained. MnOx and amorphous carbon composite (MnOx-aC) were prepared by heat treatment Mn-BTC at the same condition for comparison. 3. Materials characterization The morphology and microstructure of the samples were checked by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS G500) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, TALOS 200X). The crystal structure of prepared products was identified by the X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8) equipped with graphite-monochromatized Cu Ka radiation. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ULTRA DLD) was used for
S-4
detecting the chemical composition and electronic structure of materials. The pore diameter distribution and specific surface area of the materials were measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, ASAP2050). The X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) was performed at the beamline 02B02 and 11B of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF), beamline 11U of National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (NSRL), and beamline 20A of Taiwan Light Source (TLS). For ex-situ characterizations (mainly XPS, XRD and XAS), the samples were handled using the standard procedures, including disassembled, rinsing and transfer. The electrodes at different states of charge were disassembled and washed by deionized water and anhydrous ethanol for further testing. The quantitative analysis of Mn L-edge XAS spectra was conducted by a linear combination of the distinct line shape of Mn2+/3+/4+ reference spectra using Anaconda software based on Python. The relative concentration of Mn in different valence states can be determined by means of minimizing the residual between the experimental results and the linear combination fitted results. 4. Electrochemical measurements The as-prepared MnOx-CNFs and MnOx-aC were mixed with acetylene black and PVDF in a ratio of 7:2:1 with NMP to obtain a slurry, and then coating the slurry on
S-5
stainless steel foil. The average loading mass of active material was ~ 1-1.5 mg cm-2. The CR2032 coin cells were assembled with as-prepared cathodes, zinc foil as anode, aqueous 2 M ZnSO4 and 0.2 M MnSO4 as electrolyte and nonwoven filter paper as the separator. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on LAND workstation at various scan rates from 0.4 to 2 mV s-1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted in a frequency ranging from 0.01 Hz to 1 MHz. The galvanostatic discharge/charge test and the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) were performed in the voltage range of 0.9-1.85 V on a LAND battery testing system.

sections.heading: 1. Capacitance contribution
sections.text:
The capacitive contribution is calculated using the following equations (1) and (2)1
(1)𝒊(𝒗) = 𝒌𝟏𝒗 + 𝒌𝟐𝒗𝟏/𝟐
(2)𝒊(𝒗)/𝒗𝟏/𝟐 = 𝒌𝟏𝒗𝟏/𝟐 + 𝒌𝟐
where i, k1v, and k2v1/2 correspond to the current response, capacitive, and ionic diffusion contribution, respectively. 2. Zn2+ diffusion coefficient
S-6
The Zn2+ diffusion coefficient can be calculated from the low-frequency plots of
EIS results using the equation (3) below:2
(3)𝑫 = 𝑹𝟐𝑻𝟐
𝟐𝑨𝟐𝒏𝟒𝑭𝟒𝑪𝟐𝝈𝟐
where R is the gas constant, T is the absolute temperature; A is the surface area of electrode; n is the number of electrons per molecule during oxidation; F is the Faraday constant; C is the concentration of zinc ion, and σ is the Warburg factor, which is equaled to the slopes of Z’-ω-1/2 and the Z’ is imaginary resistance, and ω is the angular speed.
The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was also used to measure
the diffusion of ions based on the following equation (4):3
(4)𝑫 = 𝟒 𝝅𝝉( 𝒏𝒎𝑽𝒎 𝑺 ) 𝟐 ( 𝜟𝑬𝒔 𝜟𝑬𝝉) 𝟐
where τ is the constant current pulse time (s); nm and Vm are the mole number (mol) and molar volume (cm3 mol-1); S is the electrode-electrolyte interface area; ΔEs is the steady-state voltage change caused by current pulse; ΔEτ is the voltage changes during the constant current pulse.
